doc.title: Paolo Sorrentino stops work on 'complicated' Berlusconi movie
doc.author: Catherine Shoard
doc.description: The director, who won an Oscar for The Great Beauty, has shelved plans for a biopic of the former Italian prime minister, and will instead work on a second series of The Young Pope
doc.tags: Paolo Sorrentino,Film,Culture,The Young Pope,Television & radio,Silvio Berlusconi,Biopics

main.p: Paolo Sorrentino, the Italian film-maker who has made a career of movies focusing on the loneliness of ageing playboys with enormous power, is no longer working on a biopic of Silvio Berlusconi.

The film, titled Loro, had been pencilled in to shoot next summer, but in a new interview, Sorrentino said: “[I]t is a complicated story and it is not always possible to do the film that you want to do.”

Loro had not been regarded as an especially controversial project, with reports saying it was “expected to be a depiction of Berlusconi’s world, but not a scathing sterile criticism”. The Hollywood Reporter speculates that funding may been hard to secure given Italy’s shaky finances and the stated lack of interest in the project by Medusa, which co-financed Youth and The Great Beauty, and which is owned by Berlusconi.

Instead of the film, Sorrentino will work on a second season of big-budget series The Young Pope, which has been a huge success in Italy, although viewing figures in the UK have been less impressive. The series, which stars Jude Law and Diane Keaton, premieres in the US early next year.
